posts.title: Passengers Suffer as Crowded Field Puts Pressure on Europe’s Airlines
posts.text: Weaker carriers have fallen by the wayside amid fierce competition, while others have been hit by bad luck. The result: thousands of canceled flights.

posts.title: Three Courses, 20 Euros: The Affordable Dining Renaissance in Paris
posts.text: The Los Angeles area, for all of its culinary diversity, has not historically been thought of as a haven for bread lovers. The area has a reputation as a place where gluten fears to tread.

posts.title: Watch the High-Flying Physics of a Plant’s Exploding Fruits
posts.text: Three undergradute physics majors and their professor worked out how the hairyflower wild petunia shoots tiny seeds more than 20 feet through the air

posts.title: How the Shape of Your Ears Affects What You Hear
posts.text: We’re able to locate sound because our brains grasp the shape of our ears. When that shape changes, we need time and practice to adapt. Ears are a peculiarly individual piece of anatomy.

posts.title: New Contemporary Institute Reverberates in Richmond’s Historic Landscape
posts.text: With an increase in extreme weather expected in the years to come, forests could be changed permanently as the world continues to warm

posts.title: Forests Protect the Climate. A Future With More Storms Would Mean Trouble.
posts.text: The center, which will open in April, takes a bold look at race and other social issues that still resonate in the region as well as the nation. A new Institute for Contemporary Art is set to open.
